Description: Brass pricket lampstand with three rounded feet and short legs supporting a flaring lower element decorated with horizontal grooves. The lower circumference has six knobs, one above each leg and the others spaced equidistantly between them; each leg is strengthened by a strut behind it. At the top of the lower element is a baluster holding the shaft, which apparently extends right through the lower element, showing as a knob on its underside. The shaft, which thickens in the middle and tapers again to its top, is seven sided. At the top is another baluster, holding the pricket; the latter tapers from a rounded section to square. Heavily corroded. Surface colouration: patchy dark and light green, with large turquoise-coloured areas at the bottom.
Curator's comments: Analyses: (shaft): copper: 72.8; lead: 7.1; tin: 2.14; zinc: 12.6. (foot): copper: 71.0; lead: 10.5; tin: 1.98; zinc: 11.3. The metal constituents of the two analyses are not far one from the other; there is no doubt that they belong together.

Near: two examples from Homs, Syria: Ross, M.C., 1962. ‘Catalogue of the Byzantine and early mediaeval antiquities in the Dumbarton Oaks collection’. Washington : Dumbarton Oaks Research Library and Collection, No. 39; Emery, W.B., and Kirwin, L.P., 1938. ‘The royal tombs of Ballana and Qustul’. Cairo : Government Press, pl. 99, B.90-91; compare a lampstand in a miniature painting in a volume of the Gospels dated to ad 586: Mango, M.M., 1986. ‘Silver from early Byzantium : the Kaper Koraon and related treasures’. Baltimore : Trustees of the Walters Art Gallery, p. 99, fig. 11.8. The Times, 14 May 1923; Journal of Egyptian Archaeology 1923 Vol.9.
Bibliographic references: Lamp / Catalogue of the Lamps in the British Museum (3926)
Xanthopoulou 2010 / Les lampes en bronze à l’époque paléochrétienne (CD 6.001)
Condition: fair (heavily corroded and incomplete - top missing)
